elements.content: A 3D heterothiometallic cluster-based metal–organic framework was constructed from the new oligomeric decanuclear heterothiometallic building clusters [W2(μ3-S)6(μ4-S)2Cu8]4+, tetradentate 3-abpt units (3-abpt = 4-amino-3,5-bis­(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole), and CN– bridges. It possesses an unprecedented (3,11)-connected architecture, luminescence, and highly sensitive 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) sensing properties in both organic and aqueous media.

It possesses an unprecedented (3,11)-connected architecture, luminescence, and highly sensitive 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNP) sensing properties in both organic and aqueous media.

elements.content:
A unique decanuclear heterothiometallic cluster-based MOF exhibits unprecedented (3,11)-connected topology and highly sensitive 2,4,6-trinitrophenol detection in both organic and aqueous media.

Introduction

Cluster-based metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted significant recent attention because of their fascinating architectures and topologies, as well as various functionalities. However, the crystal engineering of cluster-based MOFs still faces great challenges in developing diverse and novel building clusters. Most reported cluster-based MOFs are synthesized from clusters with a narrow range of 3D structures, severely reducing the architectural flexibility. Clusters with unusual structures are urgently needed to enhance the diversity of cluster-based MOFs and thereby the prospects of achieving specific functions.

A unique decanuclear heterothiometallic cluster-based MOF exhibits unprecedented (3,11)-connected topology and highly sensitive 2,4,6-trinitrophenol detection in both organic and aqueous media.

Introduction

Cluster-based metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted significant recent attention because of their fascinating architectures and topologies, as well as various functionalities. However, the crystal engineering of cluster-based MOFs still faces great challenges in developing diverse and novel building clusters. Most reported cluster-based MOFs are synthesized from clusters with a narrow range of 3D structures, severely reducing the architectural flexibility. Clusters with unusual structures are urgently needed to enhance the diversity of cluster-based MOFs and thereby the prospects of achieving specific functions.

elements.content: Nitroaromatic compounds (NACs) are explosive and are toxic contaminants and are therefore environmental concerns. Among the NACs, TNP possesses a higher explosive capacity than 2,4,6-trinitrotoluene (TNT) and is extensively applied in the dyes, matches, glass, fireworks, and leather industries. TNP has also been confirmed as a highly toxic pollutant because of its mutagenic properties. TNP may contaminate the environment such as soil and aquatic systems during its commercial production and use. Thus, the development of highly sensitive TNP sensors is urgently needed. Luminescence-based sensors have been developed to detect NACs because of their simplicity, sensitivity, and low cost. Pioneering work on a luminescent MOF (LMOF) for the highly sensitive detection of 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT) revealed the significant promise of such LMOF materials for the sensing of NACs. NAC sensing by LMOFs is based on luminescence quenching by electron transfer or energy transfer (or a combination of the two) between the LMOFs and the NACs. If the emission band of the LMOFs and the absorption band of the NACs overlap efficiently, then energy transfer may occur and will markedly improve the fluorescence quenching efficiency and sensivity. , LMOFs with good overlap of their emission spectra with the absorption spectrum of TNP are therefore urgently needed as TNP sensors.

elements.content: Heterothiometallic clusters with very rich cluster skeletons exist. Accordingly, the increasing research interest has been attracted by Mo­(W)/S/Cu heterothiometallic cluster-based MOFs in recent years for their fascinating architectures as well as diverse applications in solvatochromism, adsorption, and nonlinear optics. For example, square-pyramidal cluster [WS4Cu5]3+ with a 4-connected manner can afford a 3D diamondoid network; nest clusters [WOS3Cu3]+ in 6- and 4-connected manners can be used to generate 3D “ACS” and diamondoid frameworks, respectively, and 3D frameworks can be obtained from 4- or 8-connected planar “open” clusters [WS4Cu4]2+. Moreover, several heterothiometallic cluster-based MOFs have been found to exhibit luminescence. However, MOFs based on oligomeric Mo­(W)/S/Cu building clusters are scarce, and luminescent heterothiometallic cluster-based MOFs are thus largely unexplored for sensing NACs. Herein, we report the solvothermal synthesis of a novel 3D oligomeric decanuclear [W2(μ3-S)6(μ4-S)2Cu8]4+ cluster-based MOF {[W2(μ3-S)6(μ4-S)2Cu8(CN)4(3-abpt)]·CH3CN·H2O} n (1) (3-abpt = 4-amino-3,5-bis­(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole), a structural study revealing an unprecedented binodal (3,11)-connected network for 1, and the first use of a luminescent heterothiometallic cluster-based MOF for sensing TNP.

elements.content: All experiments related to synthesis and characterization were carried out in air. Solvents DMF and CH3CN and chemicals CuCN and NH4SCN were purchased commercially and used without further purification. (NH4)2WS4 and the 3-abpt ligand were prepared according to literature procedures. The elemental analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a VARIOEL III microanalyzer. The infrared spectrum (4000–400 cm–1) of 1 was recorded as a KBr disc using a Nicolet Nexus 470 Fourier transform spectrometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern was recorded using a Bruker D8 diffractometer (Cu Kα1 radiation). Steady-state luminescence spectra were recorded with a QuantaMaster 40 (Photon Technology International, Inc.). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed at heating rate of 10 °C min–1 and a N2 flow rate of 50 cm3 min–1 with a TGA/1100SF thermal analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All experiments related to synthesis and characterization were carried out in air. Solvents DMF and CH3CN and chemicals CuCN and NH4SCN were purchased commercially and used without further purification. (NH4)2WS4  and the 3-abpt ligand were prepared according to literature procedures. The elemental analyses for C, H, and N were carried out on a VARIOEL III microanalyzer. The infrared spectrum (4000-400 cm-1) of 1 was recorded as a KBr disc using a Nicolet Nexus 470 Fourier transform spectrometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern was recorded using a Bruker D8 diffractometer (Cu Kα1 radiation). Steady-state luminescence spectra were recorded with a QuantaMaster 40 (Photon Technology International, Inc.). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed at heating rate of 10 °C min-1 and a N2 flow rate of 50 cm3 min-1 with a TGA/1100SF thermal analyzer.

elements.content: A 6.0 mL DMF and CH3CN (v/v = 1:1) solution of (NH4)2WS4 (0.0350 g, 0.100 mmol), CuCN (0.0271 g, 0.300 mmol), NH4SCN (0.0152 g, 0.200 mmol), and 3-abpt (0.0476 g, 0.200 mmol) was sealed in a screw-capped vial. The mixed solution was stirred for 2 h and then held at 90 °C for 36 h. After being cooled to ambient temperature at a rate of 5 °C h–1, red crystals of 1 were collected, thoroughly washed with Et2O, and dried in air. Yield: 0.0422 g (55% based on W). Anal. calcd for C18H15N11OS8Cu8W2: C, 14.09; N, 10.04; H, 0.98%. Found: C, 14.02; N, 10.11; H, 0.92%. IR (KBr pellets, cm–1): 3433 (vs), 2919 (w), 2374 (s), 2147 (vs), 1664 (vs), 1383 (m), 1090 (s), 805 (m), 698 (m), 441 (vs).

elements.content: A single crystal of 1 with suitable dimensions (0.18 × 0.15 × 0.12 mm3) for X-ray diffraction analysis was selected directly from the above synthesis experiment and mounted with grease on the top of a glass fiber for crystallographic data collection. All measurements on 1 were performed with a Bruker D8 VENTURE X-ray diffractometer with monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Cell parameters were refined on all observed reflections by using the APEX3 program. The collected data were reduced using the program APEX3, and an absorption correction (multiscan) was applied. Lorentz and polarization effects were applied to correct the reflection data. The crystal structure of 1 was solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXTL-97 software package. All non-hydrogen atoms except those from solvents were in anisotropic mode. A summary of the key crystallographic information is listed in . More detailed crystallographic data have been given in the cif file (CCDC 1497401).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure Determination

A single crystal of 1 with suitable dimensions (0.18 × 0.15 × 0.12 mm3) for X-ray diffraction analysis was selected directly from the above synthesis experiment and mounted with grease on the top of a glass fiber for crystallographic data collection. All measurements on 1 were performed with a Bruker D8 VENTURE X-ray diffractometer with monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Cell parameters were refined on all observed reflections by using the APEX3 program. The collected data were reduced using the program APEX3, and an absorption correction (multiscan) was applied. Lorentz and polarization effects were applied to correct the reflection data. The crystal structure of 1 was solved by direct methods and refined on F  2  by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELXTL-97  software package. All non-hydrogen atoms except those from solvents were in anisotropic mode. A summary of the key crystallographic information is listed in . More detailed crystallographic data have been given in the cif file (CCDC 1497401).

A stable CH3CN suspension of 1 was prepared by adding 1 mg of ground sample to 3 mL of CH3CN with 30 min of ultrasonication and a 2 day deposition. CH3CN solutions (5 mM) of NACs [NB, 2,4-DNT, TNT, and TNP] were gradually added to the above suspension at room temperature. CH3CN mixtures (5 mM, 90 μL) or solutions of other organic compounds such as toluene, MeOH, EtOH, hexane, tetrahydrofuran (THF), CH2Cl2, CHCl3, DMF, N,N′-dimethylacetamide (DMAC), and nitromethane were applied as quenchers to check the selectivity of 1. The emission of mixtures was then measured at room temperature. The sample was recovered by centrifugation after the quenching experiments and washed several times with CH3CN for PXRD analysis.

Luminescence Sensing Experiments

In CH3CN Medium

A stable CH3CN suspension of 1 was prepared by adding 1 mg of ground sample to 3 mL of CH3CN with 30 min of ultrasonication and a 2 day deposition. CH3CN solutions (5 mM) of NACs [NB, 2,4-DNT, TNT, and TNP] were gradually added to the above suspension at room temperature. CH3CN mixtures (5 mM, 90 μL) or solutions of other organic compounds such as toluene, MeOH, EtOH, hexane, tetrahydrofuran (THF), CH2Cl2, CHCl3, DMF, N,N'-dimethylacetamide (DMAC), and nitromethane were applied as quenchers to check the selectivity of 1. The emission of mixtures was then measured at room temperature. The sample was recovered by centrifugation after the quenching experiments and washed several times with CH3CN for PXRD analysis.

In Aqueous Medium

A stable H2O suspension of 1 was achieved by adding 1 mg of a ground sample to 3 mL of H2O with 30 min of ultrasonication and 2 days of deposition. A 1 mM H2O solution of TNP was gradually added to the above suspension. The emissions of mixtures were then measured at room temperature. The sample was recovered by centrifugation after the quenching experiment and washed several times with H2O for PXRD analysis.

elements.content: The detection limit was estimated according to the method used in the literature. The luminescence emission spectra of the probe were recorded five times, and the standard deviation of a blank measurement was obtained. The detection limit was calculated with the following equation: detection limit = 3σ/k (k, slope; σ, standard).
elements.clean_text:
Determination of the Detection Limit

The detection limit was estimated according to the method used in the literature. The luminescence emission spectra of the probe were recorded five times, and the standard deviation of a blank measurement was obtained. The detection limit was calculated with the following equation: detection limit = 3σ/k (k, slope; σ, standard).

elements.content: 1 was obtained from the solvothermal reaction between (NH4)2WS4, CuCN and 3-abpt in DMF/CH3CN solution. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis demonstrates that 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic crystal system with the Pmn21 space group and reveals an unprecedented (3,11)-connected framework, assembled from the new oligomeric decanuclear W/S/Cu building cluster [W2(μ3-S)6(μ4-S)2Cu8]4+, little-used tetradentate 3-abpt, and bidentate CN– bridges (, S1, and S2). The asymmetric unit has half of a decanuclear [W2(μ3-S)6(μ4-S)2Cu8]4+ cluster, half of a 3-abpt ligand, two cyanide bridges, and half each of CH3CN and H2O solvent molecules (Figure S3). The structural analysis indicates that each C 2v -symmetric decanuclear cluster [W2(μ3-S)6(μ4-S)2Cu8]4+ is linked to another four decanuclear clusters through single CN– bridges, forming 2D (4,4) networks in the [101] plane. These networks are linked with each other by CN– bridges, affording a 3D 8-connected framework, and the complexity of the 3D 8-connected framework is further increased by the incorporation of 3-connected 3-abpt units, forming a 3D (3,11)-connected framework (Scheme S1). As shown in , the building cluster of 1 contains two W atoms, eight Cu atoms, six μ3-S, and two μ4-S atoms and represents the first decanuclear cluster in the field of heterothiometallic cluster chemistry. The decanuclear [W2(μ3-S)6(μ4-S)2Cu8]4+ cluster exhibits a novel dimeric Mo­(W)/S/Cu­(Ag) cluster skeleton and can be regarded as two distorted pentanuclear “open” [WS4Cu4]2+ clusters linked through two μ4-S atoms (). Two W atoms in this decanuclear cluster show tetrahedral coordination geometries: W1 is bonded by four μ3-S atoms, while W2 is coordinated by two μ3-S and two μ4-S atoms. The average lengths of the W-μ3-S and W-μ4-S bonds are 2.230 and 2.227 Å, respectively. The eight Cu atoms have four kinds of coordination environments in the decanuclear [W2(μ3-S)6(μ4-S)2Cu8]4+ cluster (). The Cu1, Cu2, and Cu4 atoms all show tetrahedral coordination geometries but possess different coordination environments. Cu1 is linked by two μ3-S atoms, one μ4-S atom, and one cyanide bridge. Cu2 is bonded by two μ3-S atoms, one cyanide bridge, and one N atom from the pyridine group of the 3-abpt ligand. Cu4 is surrounded by one μ3-S atom, one μ4-S atom, one cyanide bridge, and one N atom from the 1,2,4-triazole group of the 3-abpt ligand. In contrast, the Cu3 atom has a triangular coordination geometry consisting of bonds to one μ3-S atom, one μ4-S atom, and one cyanide group.

(b) Unprecedented binodal (3,11)-connected topology of 1, in which the green and red balls represent the decanuclear [W2(μ3-S)6(μ4-S)2Cu8]4+ clusters and the tetradentate 3-abpt units, respectively.

elements.content: Each 3-abpt ligand links two decanuclear building clusters by its two pyridyl N atoms and one decanuclear cluster through two 1,2,4-triazole N atoms (). The 3-abpt ligand is therefore in a tetradentate 3-connected mode, which is rare in MOFs. Each decanuclear [W2(μ3-S)6(μ4-S)2Cu8]4+ cluster links another eight decanuclear building clusters through single CN– bridges and the pyridyl N or 1,2,4-triazole N atoms of three tetradentate 3-connected 3-abpt units and so exhibits overall an 11-connected manner (), the first time that this has been seen in heterothiometallic cluster-based MOFs. The Schläfli symbols of the 11-connected decanuclear building cluster and 3-connected organic tetradentate 3-abpt nodes are (34.430.514.67) and (32.4), respectively (b, 2). 1 therefore possesses a binodal (3,11)-connected network with the Schläfli symbol (32.4)­(34.430.514.67) (b). To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time that this (3,11)-connected topology has been observed in MOFs or coordination polymers.

elements.content: Dimeric Mo­(W)/S/Cu­(Ag) cluster skeletons have been reported previously, including [W2(μt-S)2(μ3-S)6Cu4] and [Mo2(μ2-O)2(μ3-S)6Cu6]2+. The [W2(μt-S)2(μ3-S)6Cu4] cluster possesses two butterfly-like [WS4Cu2] clusters linked through four μ3-S atoms, forming a dimeric hexagonal-prism-shaped cluster. [Mo2(μ2-O)2(μ3-S)6Cu6]2+ is constructed from two nest-shaped [MoOS3Cu3]+ clusters connected through two μ2-O atoms, generating a dimeric twin-nest-shaped cluster. In contrast to the extant dimeric clusters, [W2(μ3-S)6(μ4-S)2Cu8]4+ possesses very rare μ4-S atoms and a higher nuclearity. Thus, [W2(μ3-S)6(μ4-S)2Cu8]4+ affords a novel 3D MOF with a new topology, whereas dimeric [W2(μt-S)2(μ3-S)6Cu4] and [Mo2(μ2-O)2(μ3-S)6Cu6]2+ clusters exhibit only common 4-connected 2D MOFs.

elements.content: As-synthesized 1 was also characterized by PXRD. The experimental pattern of 1 matches that simulated from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data (Figure S4), which confirms the good phase purity for 1. The framework’s thermostability was investigated by TGA. As shown in Figure S5, 1 displays a weight loss of 3.81% from 55 to 200 °C, which is due to the loss of guest molecules CH3CN and H2O (calcd 3.85%). The framework of 1 starts to decompose at 270 °C.
elements.clean_text:
PXRD and TGA

As-synthesized 1 was also characterized by PXRD. The experimental pattern of 1 matches that simulated from the single-crystal X-ray diffraction data (Figure S4), which confirms the good phase purity for 1. The framework's thermostability was investigated by TGA. As shown in Figure S5, 1 displays a weight loss of 3.81% from 55 to 200 °C, which is due to the loss of guest molecules CH3CN and H2O (calcd 3.85%). The framework of 1 starts to decompose at 270 °C.

elements.content: The luminescence and NAC-sensing properties of 1 were investigated in CH3CN, a solvent in which 1 has good stability. A suspension of 1 and a solution of 3-abpt in CH3CN exhibited emission peaks at 339 and 355 nm, respectively, when excited at 284 nm (Figure S6). Different organic compounds as CH3CN solutions (90 μL, 5 mM) were then added to the suspension of 1 (1 mg in 3 mL of CH3CN), and the luminescence sensing ability of 1 was probed at room temperature. 1 is highly selective to NACs and most sensitive to TNP ().
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent NAC Sensing

The luminescence and NAC-sensing properties of 1 were investigated in CH3CN, a solvent in which 1 has good stability. A suspension of 1 and a solution of 3-abpt in CH3CN exhibited emission peaks at 339 and 355 nm, respectively, when excited at 284 nm (Figure S6). Different organic compounds as CH3CN solutions (90 μL, 5 mM) were then added to the suspension of 1 (1 mg in 3 mL of CH3CN), and the luminescence sensing ability of 1 was probed at room temperature. 1 is highly selective to NACs and most sensitive to TNP ().

elements.content: TNP, nitrobenzene (NB), 2,4-DNT, and TNT were gradually added to CH3CN suspensions of 1, which resulted in a gradual decrease in emission intensity with increasing analyte concentration (Figures S7–S10). The quenching efficiencies were estimated by the Stern–Volmer (S–V) equation: (I 0/I) = K sv[A] + 1 (K sv(M–1), quenching constant; [A], analyte molar concentration; I 0 and I, maximum luminescence intensities before and after analyte addition. The S–V plots for the analytes are almost linear under low concentrations and deviate from linearity at higher concentrations ( and S11–S14). The nonlinearity of the S–V plots for the nitroaromatic explosives may indicate that dynamic and static processes occur in luminescence quenching. c The quenching constants K sv of 1 for TNP, NB, 2,4-DNT, and TNT were found to be 7.66 × 104, 3.94 × 104, 3.10 × 104, and 1.18 × 104 M–1, respectively (Figures S11–S14). The detection limits of the assays were calculated from the 3σ/k values (k, slope; σ, standard) to be 0.81, 1.00, 1.11, and 2.15 μM for TNP, NB, 2,4-DNT, and TNT, respectively (Figures S15–S18). 1 is more sensitive for detecting TNP; the quenching constant K sv of 1 for TNP is clearly higher than those for NB, 2,4-DNT, and TNT, while the detection limit for TNP is lower than those for NB, 2,4-DNT, and TNT.

elements.content: The PXRD diffractograms of the original sample and those following the detection experiments broadly agree with each other (Figure S4), which implies that the framework integrity of 1 is maintained after the detection of the NACs. Therefore, the quenching efficiencies of 1 toward NACs are not due to the framework’s collapse. The electron-withdrawing substituents (−NO2 groups) stabilize the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) of the NACs via conjugation, facilitating electron transfer from the electron-donating framework to the electron-deficient NACs. The efficiency and sensitivity of luminescence quenching can be dramatically enhanced by energy transfer. When the fluorophore and analyte stay close to each other and the analyte’s absorption band overlaps with the fluorophore’s emission band, energy transfer will happen from the fluorophore to the nonemissive analyte. Because the emission spectrum of 1 completely overlaps with TNP’s absorption spectrum (), TNP detection for 1 with high sensitivity can be mainly ascribed to an energy-transfer process.

elements.content: TNP can contaminate the environment such as soil and H2O systems during its production and use, so the sensitive detection of TNP present in soil and groundwater is very important. This encouraged us to explore the luminescence TNP sensing of 1 in aqueous medium. The same experiments as above were carried out by applying H2O to replace CH3CN. The suspension of 1 and the solution of 3-abpt in H2O exhibited emission peaks at 382 and 390 nm, respectively, when excited at 334 nm (Figure S19). The luminescence intensity of 1 decreased gradually with the increase in TNP concentration (). The quenching efficiency was evaluated by the S–V equation (Figure S20). K sv of 1 was calculated to be 6.36 × 104 M–1 for TNP in a H2O suspension (Figure S21), which is superior to those of most TNP sensors based on MOFs (), while the detection limit for TNP was calculated to be 0.66 μM (Figure S22). The high quenching constant and low detection limit indicate that 1 is an excellent TNP sensor in H2O. As before, the structural integrity of 1 has been unambiguously demonstrated after the sensing experiment, this time in aqueous medium (Figure S4). For practical applications, it is important to assess the recycling ability of 1 for sensing TNP. The sample of 1 was obtained by centrifugation, filtration, washing, and drying. After five cycles of the TNP sensing experiment in aqueous medium, the luminescence intensities of 1 showed no obvious change (), indicating that 1 has a good recycling performance for TNP detection.

A 3D W/S/Cu cluster-based MOF has been obtained by solvothermal synthesis. It is constructed from new oligomeric decanuclear [W2(μ3-S)6(μ4-S)2Cu8]4+ building clusters, heretofore little-exploited tetradentate 3-abpt units, and CN– bridges. This novel W/S/Cu cluster-based MOF possesses an unprecedented (3,11)-connected topology and luminescence properties, and the latter has been exploited to demonstrate the highly sensitive TNP detection in both organic and aqueous media. Further studies on the synthesis of heterothiometallic cluster-based MOFs based on new building clusters and their NAC sensing properties are currently in progress.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A 3D W/S/Cu cluster-based MOF has been obtained by solvothermal synthesis. It is constructed from new oligomeric decanuclear [W2(μ3-S)6(μ4-S)2Cu8]4+ building clusters, heretofore little-exploited tetradentate 3-abpt units, and CN- bridges. This novel W/S/Cu cluster-based MOF possesses an unprecedented (3,11)-connected topology and luminescence properties, and the latter has been exploited to demonstrate the highly sensitive TNP detection in both organic and aqueous media. Further studies on the synthesis of heterothiometallic cluster-based MOFs based on new building clusters and their NAC sensing properties are currently in progress.

The mixed solution was stirred for 2 h and then held at 90 °C for 36 h.
